title: A method to boot DEFT Linux 6.0 RC - some queries follow

forumNotes.author: Holmes.Sherlock
forumNotes.content:
I downloaded [DEFT Linux 6.0 RC](http://www.deftlinux.net/download/ "External link") (deft_6_rc.iso) . Within the ISO, **\\.disk\\info** file contains the following line ``` Lubuntu 10.10 "Maverick Meerkat" - i386 (20101010) ```
which made me believe that the image is based on Ubuntu 10.10. Previously I experimented with **ubuntu-10.10-netbook-i386.iso** \& was sure that the DEFT kernel supports **live-media-path** parameter. I extracted the image in a folder called **deft-6-rc** \& my Grub4DOS menu.lst looks like ``` title DEFT 6 RC kernel /deft-6-rc/casper/vmlinuz file=/deft-6-rc/preseed/ubuntu.seed boot=casper ignore_uuid live-media-path=/deft-6-rc/casper/ initrd /deft-6-rc/casper/initrd.lz ```

The booting stopped with the error message that it can't find the squashfs image. It clearly indicates the DEFT kernel is not supporting **live-media-path** though it was supposed to do so. The I replaced the vmlinuz \& initrd.lz of the DEFT CD with the ones from the Ubuntu netbook edition. Then the USB booted fine with the same menu.lst.
BUT when the booting was done from DEFT ISO with its native kernel, then the desktop contains three icons - one evidence folder \& two other shortcuts to Time \& Date and shell. When the booting was done from the replaced Ubuntu kernel, the desktop shows only one shortcut of Install Ubuntu **9.04** (pretty amazing). My queries follow: * Is it possible that Ubuntu 10.10 supports live-media-path but Lubuntu 10.10 does not? * How does the kernel make the difference in desktop environments? * How is it giving the option of installing Ubuntu **9.04**while the kernels are of Ubuntu 10.10?

> BTW, last time I checked, Ubuntu used: > > ``` > file= > > iso-scan/filename= > ``` > > > > :smile: > Wonko > >

How does it relate to my problem? To my understanding, linux kernel vmlinuz provides the basic wrapper around the HW \& the low-level syscalls while initrd/initramfs contains a bare minimum filesystem in compressed format to be mounted @ boot-time. It's very much unlikely that either of them will incorporate a part of desktop environments like GNOME/KDE. I decompressed the original initrd where I found a folder called **evidence** . So now I got the answer that how the folder was there in original desktop. What about the other couple of shortcuts? Or it may be the shorcut files were also present in initrd, not sure about that. That's why I asked the question here. > I presume Sir Arthur Conan Doyle had higher expectations for his character's logical skills.... C'mon, like my Italian neighbor is sceptical about my logical ability, someone from India can also doubt your [sanity](http://www.thefreedictionary.com/sanity "External link").
